title: Rod Stewart and Penny Lancaster share 'amazing experience' with Maasai tribe
text:
Rod Stewart and Penny Lancaster share ‘amazing experience’ with Maasai tribe (Picture: @penny.lancaster)

Rod Stewart and his wife Penny Lancaster have revealed how humbled they were after sharing an amazing experience with the Maasai tribe.

The loved up duo have flown out to Tanzania, in East Africa, where they enjoyed some quality family time.

And while they were there, the pair decided to get a taste for the country’s culture.

Taking to Instagram, the model shared a string of photos from her time away – and it looks as though they have had a blast.

‘Amazing experience with the Maasai tribe,’ she wrote next to a video of herself joining in on their jumping ceremony.

The 48-year-old then uploaded a snap of herself posing next to a group of girls, and said: ‘These girls were either engaged or about to be engaged and we had the privilege to witness their ceremony ritual.’

The loved up duo have flown out to Tanzania (Picture: @penny.lancaster)

And it seems it was a very woman-dominated trip, as the TV personality posted a short clip of her playing ball netball with a group of school girls.

Penny stated: ‘Happiness is sharing moments like these with young women who have dreams like all the rest of us.’

Her hubby Rod also got in on the celebrations, adding: ‘Humbled by the warmth of the local Maasai tribe in one of the family homes.’

Fans were quick to comment on their posts and applauded the couple for spending time with the tribe.

They’ve experienced the country’s culture (Picture: @penny.lancaster)

Penny praised the young girls (Picture: @penny.lancaster)

‘It’s wonderful to see everyone enjoying themselves especially the young woman and children,’ one wrote while another added: ‘So beautiful to see this!!!’

Someone else said: ‘These pictures are amazing – great to see you all looking so happy.’

Rod appears to be lapping up every inch of life after he recently revealed his secret battle with prostate cancer.

During a fundraising event for Prostate Project in Surrey last month, he told the audience: ‘Two years ago I was ­diagnosed with prostate cancer. No one knows this, but I thought this was about time I told everybody.’

‘I’m in the clear, now, simply because I caught it early. I have so many tests,’ he said before addressing is natural treatment: ‘If you’re positive, and you work through it and you keep a smile on your face…’

The 74-year-old added: ‘I’ve worked for two years and I’ve just been happy, and the good Lord looked after me.’
